perturbation.original_text: All notices and other communications required or permitted hereunder shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been duly given (a) when delivered in person, (b) five (5) business days after being sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid, (c) when dispatched by electronic facsimile transmission (with confirmation of successful transmission), or (d) one (1) business day after having been dispatched by an internationally recognized overnight courier service, in each case to the appropriate Party at the address or facsimile number specified below:
perturbation.changed_text: All notices and other communications required or permitted hereunder shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been duly given (a) when delivered in person, (b) fifteen (15) business days after being sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid, (c) when dispatched by electronic facsimile transmission (with confirmation of successful transmission), or (d) ten (10) business day after having been dispatched by an internationally recognized overnight courier service, in each case to the appropriate Party at the address or facsimile number specified below:
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires that notices sent by registered or certified mail are considered duly given five business days after being sent and one business day after being sent by an internationally recognized overnight courier service. The modification extends the time for notice to be considered duly given to 15 business days for registered/certified mail and ten business days for overnight courier service. This contradicts standard legal practices, as it provides an unreasonably long period for notice, which can negatively affect legal proceedings by delaying required actions and potentially violating due process, given the agreement is governed by Nevada law, where shorter timeframes for notice are generally expected.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles regarding reasonable notice and potential due process concerns in legal proceedings under Nevada law.

perturbation.original_text: The Parties may terminate its performance of related obligations under this Agreement within thirty (30) days of receipt by the Party of written termination notice.
perturbation.changed_text: The Parties may terminate its performance of related obligations under this Agreement within ten (10) days of receipt by the Party of written termination notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a thirty (30) day period for termination upon written notice. This modification shortens the termination period to ten (10) days. Depending on the specific industry and obligations under the agreement, a ten-day termination period might be deemed unreasonably short, especially if it involves complex projects or winding down operations. This could be deemed commercially unreasonable and potentially conflict with good faith and fair dealing requirements under Nevada law if it causes undue hardship.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in contract law, which may require a commercially reasonable termination period under Nevada law.

perturbation.original_text: The Parties agree to develop a list of target cooperation projects and common goals, and consequent agreements if required, within six (6) Months of signing this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: The Parties agree to develop a list of target cooperation projects and common goals, and consequent agreements if required, within twelve (12) Months of signing this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that the parties must develop a list of cooperation projects and common goals within six months. Changing this to twelve months extends the period for establishing these fundamental aspects of the agreement. This change introduces uncertainty because, especially with a relatively short one-year term for the overall agreement, delaying the definition of target projects and goals could constitute a failure of consideration or render the agreement unenforceable. This conflicts with general contract law principles that require clear objectives and timely performance, especially under Nevada law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract law principles regarding consideration and enforceability, requiring clear objectives and timely performance under Nevada law.
